But when both types are present, the E. coli strain B is mostly affected, which suggests some kind of interaction or recombination between them. The experiment involves dividing the culture into two halves. One half is diluted 1:10^7 and plated on strain B's lawn. The other half is diluted 1:10^5 and plated on strain K's lawn. After incubation, there were 4 plumes on K and 40 on B. Wait, actually, since these are phages, each plume represents an infection event. So if you have a higher concentration of phages, more will infect the bacteria. Dilution factors mean how many cells are plated per well. Lower dilution factors (like 1e5) mean more cells are plated, increasing the chance of more infections. But let me think about what happens during the experiment. C. 1.5 percent

D. 0.1 percent

E. 0.2 percent

F. 0.3 percent

G. 0.5 percent

H. 5 percent

I. 0.02 percent

J. 0.05 percent

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

But when both types are present, the E. coli strain B is mostly affected, which suggests some kind of interaction or recombination between them. After incubation, there were 4 plumes on K and 40 on B. Wait, actually, since these are phages, each plume represents an infection event. E. 0.2 percent

F. 0.3 percent

G. 0.5 percent

H. 5 percent

I. 0.02 percent

J. 0.05 percent

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>
